data.title: Status bar requires two scrollbars -- introduced with 0.197
data.body: ![screenshot 2015-05-07 10 58 07](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/138785/7522136/14dbb3ce-f4a8-11e4-8749-1fd3fc3a39f0.png)

data.title: Save state of open windows more frequently
data.body:
We now save the open windows whenever:
- A new window is opened
- A window loses focus
- A window is closed (unless it's the last window open on linux or windows)
- `atom.exit()` is called

Refs #6466

data.title: atom auto-update clears symlink node_modules directory
data.body: I had put a symlink to a project's node_modules directory in my user folder C:\Users<username(symlink) node_modules, and when Atom updated itself it removed all production dependancies from my node_modules (leaving dev-dependancies).  Bummer!  Perhaps you could limit clearing of modules to the .atom directory.

data.title: Open Folder locking delete
data.body:
I'm using Atom 0.196.0  on Windows,
when deleting a folder and this folder is open at atom folder explorer (enpanded on left bar) 
EPERM is thrown. 

Expected Behavior:
 1) Atom shouldn't lock the folder,allowing to delete it from another running program
 2) After the folder is deleted, atom must reload the file explorer and do not list that folder nor it's files

data.title: Font rendering
data.body:
I'm having an issue on Windows 8.1

When I am coding, the font is not as clear as other text editors. 

![Here is what I see](http://i.imgur.com/xLhktNt.png) 

Compared to

![Brackets](http://i.imgur.com/yZRPXx1.png)

Before anyone says, well why not use the other, or anything along the lines of that, I can't use grunt on Brackets. It simply does not work. I like Atom as well, over Brackets. However, the font rendering is really hurting my eyes. I like my text around 11-12px but have to increase the size, just to go easier on my eyes.

Is there any CSS to help? I've tried 

```
-webkit-font-smoothing: antialiased;

-webkit-font-smoothing: none;

-webkit-font-smoothing: none/antialiased/subpixel-antialiased;
```

but none of them make a difference. I am using Source Code Pro, but even Ubuntu, or Droid Sans, there's no difference.

data.title: Change open buffer file path when cutting and pasting files #feature
data.body: At the moment when you cut and paste from within the atom ui, open buffers still point to the old location. When you save it recreates the old file, even if you didn't actually change the contents of the buffer. I think this would be very useful since 1. it's common to check the content of a file before moving it. 2. When you select the file to cut/paste it opens a buffer anyway, before you right click cut.

data.title: language selection ^ + shift + L works only with cursor
data.body:
If I select a document in the tree view and then press ctrl shift L, nothing happens. However, when I click inside the document, so that the cursor appears, the combination works fine.

I would like to be able to chose the language immediately after having opened a document, not after having started editing it.

data.title: excludeVcsIgnoredPaths: false seems to be ignored
data.body:
Hi all,
first of all I would make my congrats for your project.
I leave SBT3 for your editor and I'm proud of my choice.
However i'm experiencing a bug on `excludeVcsIgnoredPaths` setting in config file.
The problem is that even if is set to false the project tree doesn't show the ignored files and folders in the root directory.
I tried to close and reopen the project but it didn't work.
My Atom version is 0.196.0.

I hope this help you solving the problem,
thanks in advantage.

Have a nice coding day.

data.title: "reveal in tree view" does not always put tree view selection on revealed file
data.body:
Atom 0.196.0
Mac OS X 10.10.3

"Reveal in tree view" does not always put tree view selection on revealed file.  It seems to depend on the previous selection/collapse state of the tree view.  Here's an example of a repro:

![treeview](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/80917/7506811/06d06e0c-f41a-11e4-861f-22bfcaa77251.gif)

Note that if you just collapse the tree and then reveal the file, it works fine, but if you change the selection to the other directory, then collapse the tree, then choosing "reveal in treeview" expands the tree to reveal the correct file, but the selection stays on the root directory.

data.title: scrolling behavior while mouse-selecting whole lines of text is hard to control
data.body:
Atom v.0.196.0
Mac OS X 10.10.3

Trying to select text that spans more than just the visible scroll region is much more difficult in Atom than in other editors when selecting entire lines because of the auto-scrolling behavior.  When you stretch a selection past the edge of the scroll region, the editor scrolls to accommodate you, but once you overshoot your destination, pulling back starts scrolling back in the other direction even though it's not necessary.  Most other editors will only scroll when necessary.

Steps:
1. open a file that is at least twice as long as what you can display in your window
2. make sure you're scrolled to the top
3. triple-click and hold somewhere to begin selecting entire lines
4. drag down just past the bottom of the window, causing the window to scroll
5. once you've scrolled all the way to the bottom (it's important here that you scroll at least past the point where the top of the selection scrolls out of the window), pretend you overshot the bottom of what you wanted selected by a few lines and you actually want the selection to end at the 10th line from the bottom of the file.  continue to hold the mouse button down while you move your mouse back up to that line.
6. observe that if you move your mouse up past about the 4th line from the bottom of the window, it actually starts scrolling back up and will keep going until the top of your selection is visible.  This makes it difficult to get the selection to stop on a specific line because you have to time the scrolling to get your target line within 4 lines of the bottom of the window.

Expected: after mouse movement downward causes a scroll, moving the mouse back up into the window should not cause scrolling back in the other direction unless you attempt to move the end of the selection past the top of the visible part of the file.

data.title: Atom crashes opening directory
data.body:
## Steps to reproduce:
1. Open directory (via `atom` in the terminal or CMD+O in the already open app)
2. Observe "The editor has crashed" dialog

Some directories work fine and others cause a crash. I can't see any difference between successful and failing directories.

[Crash report](https://gist.github.com/jfsiii/e9e6d2ee8905ba8d93b7)

data.title: Keep the cursor in view when changing font size
data.body:
Fixes #4084 

The spec is failing but it really shouldn't be... it looks like it's because `DisplayBuffer::getVisibleRowRange` seems to always return `[0, 0]` when running specs, which `TextEditorElement::getLast/FirstVisibleScreenRow()` makes use of. @nathansobo any idea what might be going on there?

/cc @atom/feedback

data.title: Fix some integration test flakiness
data.body: Refs #6521 (May fix, but I'm not sure)

data.title: Auto Indent isn't idempotent
data.body:
I'm using Atom 0.196.0 on Ubuntu. I thought it might have been a plugin causing the problem, but you can see from the video below that the bug exists in safe mode too.

It seems like I can pretty reliably get Auto Indent to do the right thing if I strip all indentation before triggering it. I know this was working in 0.188, but because you don't [provide a PPA](https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/2956) or any other [automated update mechanism](https://github.com/atom/atom#debian-linux-ubuntu) I don't get every version.

![autoindent](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/324999/7495413/c71c54ee-f3db-11e4-9ae1-015be3e722f8.gif)

data.title: Show invisibles only when selecting text
data.body:
I tried searching for a similar issue here and I didn't find anything that directly addresses what I want, though #3249 (which I have subscribed to) is what I want, just asked for in a very roundabout way.

In short: we should have an option to only display invisibles within a selection. Showing them all the time is too noisy, not showing them at all loses their power, and turning them off and on when I want to see them is annoying. I'm aware that with CSS we cannot achieve what is required (hence unresolved #3249, and accompanying [forum post](https://discuss.atom.io/t/atom-is-so-powerful-that-it-blows-my-mind/294/17?)) due to the underlayer controlling the background highlight. So this will presumably be something that atom must provide from within the core.

If this request appeals more as something that's more generic (and allow us to achieve what we want with CSS) you could actually just attach a `.selected` class to all elements (scopes) that are within the selection (obviously a selection part-way through an element will require an inner span injected with just the `.selected` class). This way, we can do what we want in regards to the invisibles, but package developers may find interesting ways to use this selection class/scope for other purposes.

data.title: no mnemonics in menus (File, Edit, ...)
data.body:
My system:
Linux
Desktop: KDE 4.14.6

In the menus there are any mnemonics shown at all!
(the menu buttons themselves show mnemonics when pressing ALT)
E.g. in File menu:

```
New Window
New File
Open File
...
```

don't show any mnemonics. Also when pressing "ALT" while menu is opened.
Nevertheless, mnemonics seem to be there (but not shown). If I press "n" while in File menu (found out by guessing) Atom opens a new file.

data.title: Comments break code folding
Option-Click on code fold arrow (bug/enhancement)
data.body:
When option-clicking an arrow in the gutter for code folding I expect it to do a recursive fold at that level, as of right now that functionality is not implemented. As an example if I am at the root of a class with methods and I option click on the class-level arrow I would expect it to act as the "Fold All" command. But if I were to only option-click on the private label (in say a ruby class) I would expect it to fold the entire private section AND all underlying methods.

Unsure if this would be a bug or enhancement, assuming the latter.

data.title: Cursor position forgotten between tabs
data.body:
When you are working in multiple files and going back and forth between the file tabs, the cursor position for that tab is forgotten and you can't type text right away.

This is rather frustrating behaviour, as it forces you to grab your mouse and click somewhere in the code before you can start typing.

Sublime remembers the cursor position per tab/file, so that when you go back to a tab, the cursor is at the position where you left off, and you can start typing right away.

Can this be enabled for Atom as well? I couldn't find a package that does it.

data.title: Syntax settings error with split panes
data.body:
Normally, I'd report this to the [syntax-settings](https://github.com/cam-stitt/atom-syntax-settings) repo, but issues are disabled on it.

When writing Python code with panes split vertically, I get the following error whenever I save:

```
TypeError: Cannot read property 'setShowInvisibles' of null
  at TextEditorView.module.exports.TextEditorView.setShowInvisibles (C:\Users\Jacob\AppData\Local\atom\app-0.196.0\resources\app.asar\src\text-editor-view.js:360:28)
  at Object.module.exports._loopAndSetSettings (C:\Users\Jacob\.atom\packages\syntax-settings\lib\syntax-settings.coffee:83:9)
  at Object.module.exports._setSyntaxSettings (C:\Users\Jacob\.atom\packages\syntax-settings\lib\syntax-settings.coffee:72:6)
  at Object.module.exports._loadSettingsForEditorView (C:\Users\Jacob\.atom\packages\syntax-settings\lib\syntax-settings.coffee:59:8)
  at Object.<anonymous> (C:\Users\Jacob\.atom\packages\syntax-settings\lib\syntax-settings.coffee:52:10)
  at bound (C:\Users\Jacob\AppData\Local\atom\app-0.196.0\resources\app.asar\node_modules\cheerio\node_modules\lodash\dist\lodash.js:729:21)
  at TextBuffer.module.exports.Emitter.emit (C:\Users\Jacob\AppData\Local\atom\app-0.196.0\resources\app.asar\node_modules\emissary\lib\emitter.js:118:15)
  at TextBuffer.module.exports.TextBuffer.saveAs (C:\Users\Jacob\AppData\Local\atom\app-0.196.0\resources\app.asar\node_modules\text-buffer\lib\text-buffer.js:921:21)
  at TextBuffer.module.exports.TextBuffer.save (C:\Users\Jacob\AppData\Local\atom\app-0.196.0\resources\app.asar\node_modules\text-buffer\lib\text-buffer.js:899:19)
  at TextEditor.module.exports.TextEditor.save (C:\Users\Jacob\AppData\Local\atom\app-0.196.0\resources\app.asar\src\text-editor.js:592:26)
  at Pane.module.exports.Pane.saveItem (C:\Users\Jacob\AppData\Local\atom\app-0.196.0\resources\app.asar\src\pane.js:523:18)
  at Pane.module.exports.Pane.saveActiveItem (C:\Users\Jacob\AppData\Local\atom\app-0.196.0\resources\app.asar\src\pane.js:506:19)
  at Workspace.module.exports.Workspace.saveActivePaneItem (C:\Users\Jacob\AppData\Local\atom\app-0.196.0\resources\app.asar\src\workspace.js:585:35)
  at atom-workspace.atom.commands.add.core:save (C:\Users\Jacob\AppData\Local\atom\app-0.196.0\resources\app.asar\src\workspace-element.js:310:30)
  at CommandRegistry.module.exports.CommandRegistry.handleCommandEvent (C:\Users\Jacob\AppData\Local\atom\app-0.196.0\resources\app.asar\src\command-registry.js:238:29)
  at C:\Users\Jacob\AppData\Local\atom\app-0.196.0\resources\app.asar\src\command-registry.js:3:61
  at KeymapManager.module.exports.KeymapManager.dispatchCommandEvent (C:\Users\Jacob\AppData\Local\atom\app-0.196.0\resources\app.asar\node_modules\atom-keymap\lib\keymap-manager.js:519:16)
  at KeymapManager.module.exports.KeymapManager.handleKeyboardEvent (C:\Users\Jacob\AppData\Local\atom\app-0.196.0\resources\app.asar\node_modules\atom-keymap\lib\keymap-manager.js:354:22)
  at HTMLDocument.module.exports.WindowEventHandler.onKeydown (C:\Users\Jacob\AppData\Local\atom\app-0.196.0\resources\app.asar\src\window-event-handler.js:178:20)
```

The error doesn't seem to break anything (the file saves fine and the editor isn't visually affected), but it sure is annoying.

data.title: "snip" and all custom snippets not working
data.body:
After installing the last update the default snippets work as usual but none of my custom snippets work or are listed in the Available Snippets list. I've also noticed that the "snip" snippet does not work. I'm using Atom version 0.196.0 on OS X 10.10.3. Here is the custom snippet I mentioned earlier:

```
'.text.html':
    'HTML5 Skeleton':
      'prefix': 'html5'
      'body': """
      <!doctype html>
      <html>
      <head>
      <meta charset="utf-8">
      <title></title>
      </head>
      <body> 
      </body>
      </html>
      """
```

I've tried clearing the snippets.cson file in case there was some erroneous code but the "snip" snippet still doesn't work. Saving and closing also appears to have no affect. Thanks!

data.title: Use React with addons
data.body:
This makes [React addons](https://facebook.github.io/react/docs/addons.html) available on `atom.React.addons`.

Without this change, developers using `React.addons` either need to pull in a completely different React build that includes addons (bad), or use addons from another react module (also bad, because the module may have diverged from `atom.React`).

data.title: Bump settings-view@0.197.0
data.body: This includes the `settings-view` update with correct semver in spec fixtures upon which https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/6645 depends. :pizza:

data.title: Atom Erroneously Rejects Package For DevDependency That Isn't Binary Compatible
data.body:
Hi.

Since upgrading atom I've had to remove certain modules it seems because of binary incompatibility. Which is all fine. But I use gulp-watch which isn't used in my packages run-time, just for a development workflow. What am I doing wrong? Or is this expected? It seems not being able to use any tool you want during development is a major limitation.

![screen shot 2015-05-05 at 6 08 04 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1845/7484022/4c091ece-f352-11e4-994e-7f0ce720be1b.png)

My Package .json when it doesn't work and I get the above error:

```
{
  "name": "jibo-atom",
  "main": "./lib/main",
  "version": "1.0.1",
  "description": "Example package to open any HTML in a tab.",
  "repository": "ssh://git@git.jibo.com:7999/sdk/jibo-atom.git",
  "license": "MIT",
  "engines": {
    "atom": ">0.170.0"
  },
  "dependencies": {
    "URIjs": "^1.15.0",
    "animationcontent": "git+ssh://git@git.jibo.com:7999/spc/animationcontent.git",
    "animationutilities": "git+ssh://git@git.jibo.com:7999/spc/animationutilities.git",
    "atom-pane": "^1.0.1",
    "atom-space-pen-views": "^2.0.5",
    "basebehaviors": "git+ssh://git@git.jibo.com:7999/spc/basebehaviors.git",
    "clamp": "^1.0.1",
    "dof-controller": "git+ssh://git@git.jibo.com:7999/spc/dof-controller.git",
    "jibo-tools": "git+ssh://git@github.jibo.com:sdk/jibo-tools.git",
    "jquery": "^2.1.3",
    "keyframes-runtime": "git+ssh://git@github.jibo.com:sdk/keyframes-runtime.git",
    "lodash": "^3.7.0",
    "mkdirp": "^0.5.0",
    "npm": "^2.8.4",
    "object-assign": "^2.0.0",
    "react": "^0.13.1",
    "space-pen": "^5.1.1",
    "sub-atom": "1.0.x",
    "theorist": "1.0.2",
    "three": "^0.70.0",
    "wrench": "^1.5.8"
  },
  "devDependencies": {
    "gulp": "^3.8.11",
    "gulp-babel": "^4.0.1",
    "gulp-cached": "^1.0.4",
    "gulp-coffee": "^2.3.1",
    "gulp-sourcemaps": "^1.5.1",
    "gulp-watch": "^4.2.4"
  }
}
```

Just removing `gulp-watch` from the devDependencies makes it all work again:

```
{
  "name": "jibo-atom",
  "main": "./lib/main",
  "version": "1.0.1",
  "description": "Example package to open any HTML in a tab.",
  "repository": "ssh://git@git.jibo.com:7999/sdk/jibo-atom.git",
  "license": "MIT",
  "engines": {
    "atom": ">0.170.0"
  },
  "dependencies": {
    "URIjs": "^1.15.0",
    "animationcontent": "git+ssh://git@git.jibo.com:7999/spc/animationcontent.git",
    "animationutilities": "git+ssh://git@git.jibo.com:7999/spc/animationutilities.git",
    "atom-pane": "^1.0.1",
    "atom-space-pen-views": "^2.0.5",
    "basebehaviors": "git+ssh://git@git.jibo.com:7999/spc/basebehaviors.git",
    "clamp": "^1.0.1",
    "dof-controller": "git+ssh://git@git.jibo.com:7999/spc/dof-controller.git",
    "jibo-tools": "git+ssh://git@github.jibo.com:sdk/jibo-tools.git",
    "jquery": "^2.1.3",
    "keyframes-runtime": "git+ssh://git@github.jibo.com:sdk/keyframes-runtime.git",
    "lodash": "^3.7.0",
    "mkdirp": "^0.5.0",
    "npm": "^2.8.4",
    "object-assign": "^2.0.0",
    "react": "^0.13.1",
    "space-pen": "^5.1.1",
    "sub-atom": "1.0.x",
    "theorist": "1.0.2",
    "three": "^0.70.0",
    "wrench": "^1.5.8"
  },
  "devDependencies": {
    "gulp": "^3.8.11",
    "gulp-babel": "^4.0.1",
    "gulp-cached": "^1.0.4",
    "gulp-coffee": "^2.3.1",
    "gulp-sourcemaps": "^1.5.1"
  }
}

```

data.title: Remove babel compatibility option for legacy React versions
data.body:
This change depends on https://github.com/atom/react/pull/2.

After updating https://www.npmjs.com/package/react-atom-fork to v0.13.2 per the above PR, we need to remove the compatibility transform.
